newsitem.title: BELARUS: Russia's Gazprom resumes normal Belarus supplies.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Gazprom resumes normal Belarus supplies.

text.p: Russia's Gazprom natural gas monopoly has resumed regular deliveries to Belarus after cutting them last week when the former Soviet republic failed to pay its bills, a Belarussian government official said on Monday.
Yuri Melnikov, chief of the energy resources department, told Reuters that deliveries resumed after Belarus partially paid its bill and established a future payment schedule.
Supplies were reduced by seven million cubic metres of gas per day.
The country of 10 million people normally receives 47 million cubic metres of gas daily. Belarus imports 16 billion cubic metres of Russian gas annually.

"Gazprom has been paid $10 million. Despite all the difficulties the government located the means to find the money," said Nikolai Mochernyuk, president of the state company Beltransgaz, in a television interview on Sunday night.
He said that if Belarus failed to make promised payments, supplies would be reduced anew.
Mochernyuk has said previously that Belarus's debt to Gazprom was $204 million.
Belarus also owes Russia $50 million for past supplies and annually receives 10 million tonnes of oil for domestic needs and six million tonnes to refine for Russia at its two plants.
